text:
This question may have been asked but I can't find the thread:

*Is Grammarly Premium worth the money?* They're running a discount and I'd like to purchase a yearly subscription if it's worthwhile.

elements.text: This question may have been asked but I can't find the thread:
Is Grammarly Premium worth the money?
They're running a discount and I'd like to purchase a yearly subscription if it's worthwhile.

text:
- Headphones that don't suck
- A notepad (real or virtual)
- Laptop connected to the charger (or one with 90%+ charge)
- A bottle of water 

That's all I have when I'm (seriously) attending a virtual event.

elements.text:
- Headphones that don't suck

text: For attendees, it's gonna be something that reminds you to move. Lots of apps that do this (for me, it's my Oura ring), but, especially if the content is GOOD, you'll forget to move and likely sit folded in half for 2 hours straight. Not good.

elements.text: For attendees, it's gonna be something that reminds you to move. Lots of apps that do this (for me, it's my Oura ring), but, especially if the content is GOOD, you'll forget to move and likely sit folded in half for 2 hours straight. Not good.

text: i don't use it but a lot of people on my team do. i think it's worth it if you tend to make grammar mistakes regularly, but other than that, i wouldn't pay for it.

elements.text: i don't use it but a lot of people on my team do. i think it's worth it if you tend to make grammar mistakes regularly, but other than that, i wouldn't pay for it.

text: Gotcha! Thanks.

elements.text: Gotcha! Thanks.

text: I pay for an annual membership, and I've found value in it. I think I'm a pretty strong writer/editor, but there's always things you don't catch on your own and things you can improve on.

elements.text: I pay for an annual membership, and I've found value in it. I think I'm a pretty strong writer/editor, but there's always things you don't catch on your own and things you can improve on.

text: I think it's worth it not so much for the upsides, but because it protects the downside of sending an article to a client that has an easily avoidable error

elements.text: I think it's worth it not so much for the upsides, but because it protects the downside of sending an article to a client that has an easily avoidable error

text: <@U01075APBHB> Thank you. It'd be awesome if you could highlight a few things that helped you time and again.

elements.text: Thank you. It'd be awesome if you could highlight a few things that helped you time and again.

text: <@UUJBMDVGB> Totally agree.

elements.text: Totally agree.

text: I mean, I run all my articles through it and then I use the Chrome Extension, so it also auto-checks anything I type. Is that what you're looking for?

elements.text: I mean, I run all my articles through it and then I use the Chrome Extension, so it also auto-checks anything I type. Is that what you're looking for?

text: Gotcha! I was looking for specific edits that you make as per its suggestions. For example, they suggest a certain sentence needs to be in active voice... Is that suggestion accurate?

elements.text: Gotcha! I was looking for specific edits that you make as per its suggestions. For example, they suggest a certain sentence needs to be in active voice... Is that suggestion accurate?

text: I'd say 90% of their suggestions are accurate/I take.

elements.text: I'd say 90% of their suggestions are accurate/I take.

text: this is where i disagree with common advice. if you're a good writer and understand the mechanics and usage of active vs passive, grammarly can't help you. most software that says it detects passive voice is wrong half the time - it's not actually passive. plus, passive is not evil. it has its place in good writing.

elements.text: this is where i disagree with common advice. if you're a good writer and understand the mechanics and usage of active vs passive, grammarly can't help you. most software that says it detects passive voice is wrong half the time - it's not actually passive. plus, passive is not evil. it has its place in good writing.

text: if you don't understand passive or when/how to avoid it, then maybe a tool like grammarly is worth it

elements.text: if you don't understand passive or when/how to avoid it, then maybe a tool like grammarly is worth it

text: but then i'd argue that you should learn, and that will make your writing stronger. because you won't know when grammarly is wrong

elements.text: but then i'd argue that you should learn, and that will make your writing stronger. because you won't know when grammarly is wrong

text: I understand your point but sometimes I tend to miss certain things when I'm writing a long-form article. It's where this tool comes to help.

elements.text: I understand your point but sometimes I tend to miss certain things when I'm writing a long-form article. It's where this tool comes to help.

text:
I use it in the same way as <@UUJBMDVGB>. I use it more for catching silly things like a comma, an extra space, or a misspelled word. 
The passive suggestions don't move me to action because they feel like they don't fit in the writing. 
I have Pro but will probably not re-up my subscription the next time.

text:
I balked at paying for it initially, but Ive found its a helpful second set of eyes for small dumb stuff as <@UUJBMNRNF> said. Ive found its useful for flagging blatant errors when Im burning through high volumes of copy quickly.

Plus, we share a subscription across our org, so its worth it for them.

Microsoft Words spellcheck is pretty stellar these days, too =D

text:
Folks, IMHO delivering great content, managing existing client expectations and winning new clients are 3 different beasts to tame/ skills to acquire... Would you agree? If so, from a long-term career perspective, would it be useful to not take on all three at the same time and risk burnout? Instead, maybe tackle each of them one-at-a-time? As a freelancer, sometimes doing all 3 feels too overwhelming.

Question: Would it rather help to focus on just 1 or 2 by partnering with a team/ someone else/ getting a content job? Or is this just "grass is greener on the other side" thinking? Would partnering or getting employed also lead to similar drawbacks? Any pointers, advice or insights would be greatly appreciated. Thanks :pray::skin-tone-3:

elements.text:
